gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Herring Infection Prevalence Data, 2007-2016, EVOS Herring Program

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The Prince William Sound population of Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) is considered resource that has not recovered from the effects of the 1989 oil spill. Numerous research and monitoring programs, funded in large part by the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, provide critical information about about herring populations in Prince William Sound.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Prince William Sound Science Center, Herring Program

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Researchers from multiple institutions are working to determine why herring populations remain depressed. With funds from the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, which oversees funds from a settlement between State/Federal government and Exxon, a group of research and monitoring projects were designed to improve predictive models of herring stocks through observations and research.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The webpage for the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, which was formed to oversee restoration of the injured ecosystem through the use of the $900 million civil settlement, a part which funds Research, Monitoring, and Restoration programs in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: US Geological Survey- Marrowstone Marine Field Station
US Geological Survey- Marrowstone Marine Field Station

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The following is a publication associated with this dataset: Hershberger et al. 2016. The parasite Ichthyophonus sp. in Pacific herring. Journal of Fish Diseases 39: 309-410

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: These data are part of the Herring Program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, project numbers 070819, 10100132-I, 12120111-K, 14120111-K, and 16120111-K, which is a multi-faceted study to determine why herring populations in Prince William Sound remain depressed since the early 1990s. The project was designed to assess the prevalence and intensity of several pathogens (viral hemorrhagic septicemia virus (VHSV),viral erythrocytic necrosis (VEN), and Ichthyophonus) in herring populations from 2012 to 2016 in Prince William Sound (PWS). Other reference herring populations from Sitka, Alaska were periodically sampled outside PWS. The dataset is ten tabular data files in comma-separated values (csv) format containing standard headers including fish length, weight, positive / negative data for each pathogen, and pathogen loads, when applicable. Files are organized by year (2012 to 2016) and sample location (Stika and PWS). Additionally, a single csv file contains a summary of infection prevalence ratios (VHSV, VEN, and Icthyophonus) for PWS from 2007 to 2016. Data from 2007 to 2011 were collected under the EVOS PWS Herring Disease Program, project numbers 070819 and 10100132-I.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Following the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill, a group of herring research and monitoring projects were designed to improve predictive models of herring stocks in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska through observations and research. These data were collected in support of the EVOSTC project, entitled PWS Herring Disease Program. The data provide an indication of the current infection and disease statue of herring in PWS.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Please Contact Paul Hershberger phereshberger@usgs.gov to discuss the context for which you plan to use the data.

This material is based upon work funded by multiple entities, including the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of funding entities. Standard scientific norms for attribution, credit, and potential co-authorship should be followed when using these data including to the Owners, Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council and other sources of funding. Please let the Owner know when these data are used.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Prince William Sound Herring Program in the Gulf of Alaska Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Affected Area

gmd:individualName.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council (EVOSTC) initiated funding for the integrated research program in Prince William Sound (PWS) in 2009. The PWS Herring Survey program occurred between 2009 and 2013. The Herring Research and Monitoring (HRM) program began in 2012 and is continuing. The Herring Research and Monitoring program is administrated by the EVOSTC under five-year contracts with a total anticipated duration to be twenty-years in length, concluding in 2032. The HRM program is designed to be able to change focus every five years. This changes the types of data collected and the number of projects within the program. The overarching goal of the HRM program is to improve predictive models of herring stocks through observation and research. The monitoring efforts provide surveys of disease prevalence, adult biomass, juvenile abundance index, and condition of young of the year herring. A series of process studies are aimed at improving our understanding of individual components of the herring life cycle. These studies include determining the age at first spawn, identifying population genetic structure, analysis of herring scales for growth patterns, intensive surveys of juvenile populations and conditions, analysis of fatty acids to determine migration distances, improving validation of acoustic measurements, disease related studies, acoustic tagging, development of nonlethal sampling methods, and modeling of herring populations.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Prince William Sound Herring Disease Program (project number 2007: 070819)

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: US Geological Survey- Marrowstone Marine Field Station

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The 2012 to 2016 data in this collection is a continuation of disease monitoring conducted under the EVOSTC-funded EVOS Herring Program, project 070819, which collected data from 2007 to 2009. A leading hypothesis accounting for the decline and failed recovery of the herring population in Prince William Sound involves epizootic mortality resulting from infectious and parasitic diseases. Ongoing and past surveillance of herring diseases in PWS, initiated by Dr. Gary Marty and continued by ADF&G through the herring disease index, is extremely valuable and necessary to document changes in disease prevalence, but field surveys are unable to unequivocally demonstrate epidemiological relationships that modulate disease cycles. This proposed multi-year Herring Disease Program (HDP) consists of three components intended to provide predictive metrics that forecast future disease epidemics and offer empirical relationships useful in developing adaptive management policies to mitigate the effects of epizootic and chronic diseases. The first component involves laboratory validation of the ongoing PWS herring disease index. Long-term continuation of the herring disease index, paired with laboratory validation, is necessary to confirm the efficacy of future adaptive disease management strategies. The second component involves empirical studies intended to determine the basic epidemiological relationships between environmental and biological factors influencing infection / disease prevalence. The final component involves development of immunological and molecular tools that will be useful in predicting the potential for future disease epidemics. Combined, this three-tiered approach will provide the basic epidemiological information necessary to develop and validate adaptive management techniques intended to mitigate the effects of future herring disease outbreaks in PWS.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: PWS Herring Survey: Herring Disease Program (HDP) (project number: 2010: 10100132-I)

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: US Geological Survey- Marrowstone Marine Field Station

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The 2012 to 2016 data in this collection is a continuation of disease monitoring conducted under the EVOSTC-funded EVOS Herring Program, project 10100132-I, which collected data from 2010 to 2012. The Herring Disease Program (HDP) is part of a larger integrated effort, the PWS herring survey: Community Involvement, Outreach, Logistics, and Synthesis submitted under the BAA (outlined in a separated proposal by Dr. Scott Pegau), that is intended to identify juvenile rearing bays, measure factors limiting the success of juvenile herring, and provide recommendations for spatial and temporal coverage of future monitoring efforts. Within this integrated effort, the HDP is intended to evaluate the impact of infectious and parasitic diseases on the failed recovery of the PWS herring population by placing special emphasis on disease processes affecting juvenile cohorts. The framework for the 2010 - 2013 HDP involves a combination of field surveillance efforts and laboratory-based empirical disease process studies. Field surveillance efforts will provide continued and expanded infection and disease prevalence data for herring populations in Prince William Sound (PWS), Sitka Sound, and Puget Sound. Additionally, samples from field surveillance efforts will be processed using newly-developed disease forecasting tools to provide annual risk assessments that quantify the potential for future disease epizootics. Empirical disease process studies will provide an understanding of cause and effect epidemiological relationships between the host, pathogen, and environment; understanding of these relationships represents a first step towards developing additional disease forecasting tools. Specific emphasis will be placed on refining our understanding disease processes specific to viral hemorrhagic septicemia (VHS) and ichthyophoniasis, two primary diseases of herring in PWS.

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Original datasets were constructed in Microsoft Excel (2010) and converted to csv format for archive.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Particular embayments and geographic locations throughout Prince William Sound and Sitka Sound, Alaska

gml:TimePeriod.gml:description: Time frame represents the bounding range for files named: 2012 PWS.csv, 2013 PWS.csv, 2014 PWS.csv, 2015 PWS.csv, 2016 PWS.csv, 2012 Sitka.csv, 2013 Sitka.csv, 2014 Sitka.csv, 2015 Sitka.csv, 2016Sitka.csv

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Data available in csv format for download in the Alaska Ocean Observing System (AOOS) Gulf of Alaska data portal.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: All electronic data were spot checked and compared to the original data sheets.
We have our analytical equipment serviced and calibrated each year through service contracts with certified contractors.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Fish were collected by purse seine, cast net, beech seine, or gill net. Samples were collected by staff at the USGS – Marrowstone Marine Field Station and the Prince William Sound Science Center from their representative cruises. Samples were then transported to either the USGS – Marrowstone Marine Field Station or the ADF&G Juneau Fish Pathology Laboratory for further processing. Standard pathogen diagnostic methods and techniques described in the American Fisheries Society, Fish Health Section Blue Book: http://afs-fhs.org/bluebook/bluebook-index.php: VHSV methods: Section 2.2.7 VEN methods: Section 2.2.6 Ichthyophonus Section: 3.2.18
